Award.AwardTitle: Studies of White-Light and Black-Light Flares Using the 1.6 m New Solar Telescope (NST) at Big Bear Solar Observatory (BBSO)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This 3-year project is aimed at advancing present understanding of the origin of solar flares by taking unprecedented high-resolution observations from the newly commissioned 1.6m New Solar Telescope (NST) at the Big Bear Solar Observatory (BBSO) and numerical simulations using radiative hydrodynamic codes. The new observations by the NST are expected to extend the frontier of existing knowledge on the energy release process of flares and its impact on the deep solar atmosphere in terms of both positive and negative contrasts. The observational results will also be compared with numerical simulations in order to have a more complete physical understanding of the observed phenomena. NSF has made significant investment in supporting the BBSO's facilities in the past, in particular the NST, which has been transited from commissioning phase to operations, thus enabling routine high-quality observations of the Sun.

This comparative investigation in solar flare phenomena will enable a quantitative analysis of the energy release processes that occur not only on the Sun, but also elsewhere in the solar system and stars. Solar flares are one of the key sources of space weather, which causes adverse impacts on the Earth and its environment. Advanced understanding of the solar flare phenomenon helps improve forecasts of space weather events at their onset.

This research project has a strong educational component; it will support a female Ph.D. student and a junior researcher at the NJIT. The studies will provide a comprehensive training for the student in taking observations at the BBSO, data processing and understanding the principals of flare heating models. Therefore, the project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of this grant, a female student (Nengyi Huang) has obtained her Ph. D. degree in July, 2020 and became a junior post-doc researcher since then.

 

We have carried out several observing runs with BBSO/GST.  We analyzed the GST data in visible and near infrared, together with UV, EUV and HXR data taken by SDO, IRIS and RHESSI, respectively. Our investigations and modeling efforts show that the enhanced absorption in helium line 10830 ? is produced by precipitating electrons directly or indirectly. Figure 1 shows the comparison between the observed "negative flare" in He I 10830 ? and the modeled emission as a function of time. Panel (a) present five modeled line profiles at different times. The purple one is background (t = 0 s) before the electron precipitation and this helium line shows a very shallow (almost negatable) absorption at the center. At t= 1.7 s, we see a strong deep indicating enhanced absorption (blue). Afterwards, this line becomes emission dominated with some absorptions. The two vertical lines indicate the bandpass of the filter we used for  He I 10830 ? observation at BBSO. By integrating the intensities within this bandpass at different times, a light curve is generated from the modeling results and plotted in panel (b). The observed light curve is plotted in panel (c). As we can see, the model agrees well with the observation in terms of maximum negative contrasts (-17.1% vs. -13.7%) and the deep-peak-deep pattern of temporal variation. The negative contrasts are concentrated on the ribbon front, where the electrons precipitate and deposit their energies. These results clearly demonstrated that the leading edge of flare ribbons behaves differently from the trailing components, in which the trapped electrons are strongly involved.

 

In other studies, we show the magnetic fields vary as the flare ribbons propagate through the sunspot, in terms of field rotation in small scales and sudden increase of sunspot rotation. Other studies include precursors of a major M6.5 flare, the relationship between continuum emission and HXR emission, and the Slipping Magnetic Reconnection along a Dimming Channel during a Solar Flare, etc.
